item.title: BOE’s Bailey Urges Closer EU Trade to Reverse Brexit Damage
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey has urged the government to strike a deeper trade deal with the European Union to improve growth and “minimize negative effects” of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), at the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point to 4.25% as Donald Trump’s global trade war weighs on UK growth, in a decision that split senior officials into three groups and was made before the US President hinted at an imminent deal to lower tariffs on British exports.

item.title: Banxico See More Rate Cuts After Mexico Skirted Recession
item.description: Mexico’s central bank expects to continue to ease monetary policy gradually after the economy narrowly avoided recession.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Mexico's central bank headquarters, the Banco de Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world's largest economy.

item.title: US May Take Trump Tariff Case to Supreme Court on Friday
item.description: The Trump administration said it would ask the US Supreme Court to intervene as soon as Friday if a federal appeals court doesn’t immediately put on hold a decision finding that most of the president’s tariffs are illegal.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. Supreme Court justices signaled they are likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular social media platform TikTok in the US if it isn’t sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19.

item.title: The Economic Benefits of Paying Workers to Move
item.description: A new study finds that Tulsa’s effort to lure remote workers with $10,000 has returned four times that investment back into the local economy.
item.dc:creator: Rthvika Suvarna, Fola Akinnibi

media:content.media:description: Tulsa is the second-largest city in the state of Oklahoma and 47th-most populous city in the United States.

item.title: Hefty Cut in Polish Gas Tariffs Stokes Rate Easing Prospects
item.description: Poland’s decision to reduce gas-price tariffs by 14.8% from July bodes well for bringing down inflation and paves way for the central bank to further cut interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Traffic passes underneath district heating pipes on the Gdanski Bridge over the Vistula river in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. Russian gas deliveries across Ukraine halted on New Year’s Day after a transit contract between the two warring nations expired, with no alternative in place. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Ishiba Calls Trump to Talk Tariffs, Touts Deeper Understanding
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba initiated a phone call with US President Donald Trump to discuss tariffs, and said the two deepened their understanding.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba and Donald Trump. Photographer: Kyodo News/Kyodo News Stills

item.title: US Pending Home Sales Drop by Most Since 2022 on Mortgage Rates
item.description: Pending sales of previously owned US homes last month fell by the most since September 2022, illustrating a disappointing spring selling season as prospective buyers balk at high asking prices and borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: New homes in Boca Chica Village, Texas, US, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Residents of the tiny community near SpaceX's rocket launch site voted on May 3 to officially incorporate the area as its own city, Starbase, Texas.

item.title: S. Africa Central Bank Touts Benefit of Cutting CPI Goal to 3%
item.description: South African central bankers threw their weight firmly behind lowering their long-standing 3% to 6% inflation target, which is currently under review. The nation’s bonds rallied.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: An outdoor food market in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Central Bank Cuts Rates as Inflation Risks Ease
item.description: South Africa’s central bank resumed its easing cycle to offer support to a stuttering economy, as it forecast a more benign inflation outlook.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Lesetja Kganyago Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Kazimir Found Guilty of Bribery and Plans to Keep Job
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Peter Kazimir was convicted of bribery and fined €200,000 ($225,380) in a ruling that will cause embarrassment to the Frankfurt institution.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Peter Kazimir Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Advisers Downplay Ruling Blocking Tariffs, Cite Other Options
item.description: Senior White House officials on Thursday downplayed the implications of a court ruling that blocked a swath of President Donald Trump’s tariff measures, and expressed confidence about an appeal.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: A train enters the United States over a rail bridge on the US-Mexico border in Laredo, Texas, US, on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2025. President Donald Trump said he would likely impose tariffs on automobile, semiconductor and pharmaceutical imports of around 25%, a move that would dramatically widen the president’s trade war.

item.title: Czech Election Frontrunners Prepare State Buyout of CEZ Utility
item.description: The Czech Republic’s most popular political party pledged to seek full state ownership in power producer CEZ AS to boost energy security if it returns to government after elections due in October.
item.dc:creator: Krystof Chamonikolas

media:content.media:description: A CEZ nuclear power plant in Dukovany, Czech Republic. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: US Economy Shrinks 0.2% on Weaker Spending, Larger Trade Impact
item.description: The US economy shrank at the start of the year, restrained by weaker consumer spending and an even bigger impact from trade than initially reported.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Austria’s Andritz Expects Clarity on US Tariffs by End of Summer
item.description: One of Europe’s largest manufacturers of specialist factory machines expects clarity on US tariffs to encourage industrial firms to start making investment decisions again within weeks.
item.dc:creator: Marton Eder, Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Torrefaction reactor manufactured at an Andritz workshop in Graz, Austria.

item.title: British Virgin Islands, Bolivia Poised to Join Dirty Money List
item.description: The British Virgin Islands — a major offshore finance hub — and Bolivia, home to one of the world’s largest lithium deposits, are at risk of inclusion on a global “gray list” for not making enough progress to stem illicit flows of money.
item.dc:creator: Ben Bartenstein, Jasmina Kuzmanovic, Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: The British Virgin Islands has long been a preferred locale for the world’s wealthy to safeguard their assets.

item.title: Taiwan Says US Trade-Deal Push Continues Despite Court Ruling
item.description: Taiwan is continuing its efforts to secure a trade deal with the US, a top official said, even after a court blocked many of the tariffs that President Donald Trump has threatened to impose on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Miaojung Lin, Yvonne Man

media:content.media:description: The Port of Keelung in Keelung, Taiwan.

item.title: Starmer Acknowledges Farage’s Reform UK Is Main Labour Rival
item.description: Keir Starmer said Britain’s main opposition Conservative Party is in decline and that the choice for voters is now between his governing Labour Party and the right-wing populist Nigel Farage’s Reform UK.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Trade Strategy Roiled by Court Blocking Global Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariff strategy has been thrown into turmoil after a US court issued a rare rebuke blocking many of the import taxes he has threatened and imposed on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Erik Larson, Laura Curtis

item.title: Economic Debate Begins on Impact of ‘Military Keynesianism’
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the economic effects of a ramp up in defense spending. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Musk Exits DOGE Leaving Threadbare Agencies and Strained Workers
item.description: The full effects of a drastic cost-cutting campaign are coming into focus as its billionaire architect departs from the government
item.dc:creator: Ted Mann

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Zambia Inflation Slows to 11-Month Low as Food Prices Ease
item.description: Zambia’s annual inflation eased to an 11-month low in May as improved rains helped cool food price rises of corn grain and vegetables.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a market in Lusaka. Photographer: Zinyange Auntony/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump's ‘Liberation Day’ Tariffs Hit Legal Roadblock in US Court
item.description: Uncertainty abounds, but the US president has other ways to impose import duties
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Goldman Warns World’s Best Carry Trade at Threat From Lira Slide
item.description: The most successful carry trade in the world looks vulnerable as Turkey’s central bank allows the lira to drop, says Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: A sign displays Turkish lira rates outside a currency exchange bureau in Istanbul, Turkey, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024. Turkey's central bank will hold its next interest rate decision on Feb. 22.

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Heads to US for Latest Round of Tariff Talks
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is headed to Washington for his fourth round of trade negotiations with the US, signaling that talks will continue as expected despite a US court ruling that declared the tariffs illegal.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa

item.title: South Africa Poised for Rate Cut to Bolster Economy
item.description: The South African Reserve Bank looks set to ease borrowing costs on Thursday to support a faltering economy, before pausing to assess any further fallout from US President Donald Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Lesetja Kganyago

item.title: Poland’s World-Beating Rally Is Facing an Election Reality Check
item.description: Revved-up Polish markets will be put to the test this weekend as voters head to the polls in the biggest challenge facing Premier Donald Tusk.
item.dc:creator: Selcuk Gokoluk, Wojciech Moskwa

item.title: Bank of Korea Flags More Rate Cuts to Come as Tariffs Hit Growth
item.description: The Bank of Korea flagged the likelihood of more interest rate cuts to come after trimming borrowing costs on Thursday and slashing this year’s growth forecast as Donald Trump’s tariffs and political turmoil weigh on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: The Global Tussle For The Port of Darwin
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Host Rebecca Jones speaks to government reporter Ben Westcott and senior editor Chelsea Mes about the strategic significance of the Port of Darwin.

media:content.media:description: The access entry to the Port of Darwin. Photographer: Darrian Traynor/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Deemed Illegal, Blocked by Trade Court
item.description: The vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs were deemed illegal and blocked by the US trade court, dealing a major blow to a pillar of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: US Ally South Korea Set to Improve China Ties If Lee Wins Vote
item.description: A win for the left-of-center frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential election would likely herald more caution by Seoul over taking sides in US-China rivalry, a new effort to draw North Korea into dialogue and the potential for tension with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung speaks at a campaign event in Uijeongbu on May 20.
